intro: Lopezia bracteata, commonly known as the bracteate lupine, is a flowering plant native to the southwestern United States and northern Mexico. It belongs to the Fabaceae family, which includes legumes, and is characterized by its compound leaves and pea-like flowers. The plant typically grows in rocky or sandy soils and is adapted to arid and semi-arid environments. Lopezia bracteata has small, oval-shaped leaves and produces clusters of violet or purple flowers that bloom in the spring. It plays a role in stabilizing soils and providing nectar for pollinators in its native habitat.
